greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Iterate the map x -> A230625(x) starting at n; sequence gives number of steps to reach a prime, or -1 if no prime is ever reached.
comment: _David J. Seal_ found that the number 255987 is fixed by the map described in A230625 (or equally A287874), so a(255987) = -1. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jun 15 2017

I also observe that the numbers 1007 and 1269 are mapped to each other by that map, as are the numbers 1503 and 3751 (see the b-file submitted by _Chai Wah Wu_ for A230625). So a(1007) = a(1269) = a(1503) = a(3751) = -1. - _David J. Seal_, Jun 16 2017
See A287878 for the trajectory of 234, which ends at a prime at step 103. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jun 18 2017
See A288894 for the trajectory of 3932. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jun 18 2017
link: Sean A. Irvine, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000 (terms 2..3931 from Chai Wah Wu)
mathematica: Map[Length, Table[NestWhileList[fn, n, # != 1 && ! PrimeQ[#] &], {n, 2, 40}], {1}] - 1 (* _Robert Price_, Mar 16 2020 *)
